Yes, based on the provided information and assuming no external forces act upon them, both balls (red and blue) would fall into their respective targets.

The red ball is falling from above towards its target below it. The only force acting on this ball is gravity which pulls it downwards due to Earth’s acceleration of about 9.8 m/s² near the surface. As long as there are no obstructions or other objects affecting its trajectory, such as air resistance or friction with the ground, we can predict that the red ball will continue moving straight down until it reaches the bottom edge of the gray platform where it will then enter the red target circle.

Similarly, the blue ball is also falling but not directly towards any specific point like the red one does. Instead, it appears to be rolling along an unseen path before reaching what seems to be another target at some distance away. Without more details regarding how far these two balls travel horizontally while they're still under the influence of gravity, making predictions beyond hitting their respective targets becomes speculative.

In conclusion, given all available data points, our best guess for each scenario is that both balls hit their designated targets without interference. However, if you require further clarification or have additional questions related to physics principles involved here, feel free to ask!

Yes, based on the given information, it is likely that the red ball will eventually reach the green target area.
The blue ball has already been released from its starting position at the top edge of the image and is currently moving downwards towards the bottom edge of the image due to gravity. As long as there are no external forces acting upon the system (such as air resistance or friction), the blue ball will continue to fall until it reaches the ground.
Since the red ball is located inside the blue cup, which is also situated near the bottom edge of the image, it can be assumed that the red ball was placed within the cup before the experiment began. Therefore, when the blue ball falls through the opening of the cup, it will collide with the red ball and cause it to move upwards along the wall of the cup.
As the red ball moves up the wall of the cup, it will encounter less gravitational force pulling it down since it is now closer to the center of mass of the entire system. This means that once the red ball reaches the upper part of the cup where the opening is located, it will have enough kinetic energy to escape out into the open space above the cup.
Therefore, if all other conditions remain constant, such as the absence of any obstacles or disturbances during the experiment, we can predict that the red ball will eventually reach the green target area after being propelled out of the cup by the collision with the blue ball.

Yes, based on the given information, it is likely that the blue ball will hit the red ball at some point during its descent towards the ground. This collision would cause both balls to bounce off each other simultaneously in opposite directions.
Assuming no external forces act upon them after their initial release from rest, we can predict the motion of these two objects using classical mechanics principles such as Newton’s laws of motion.

The first law states that an object remains at rest or moves with constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force. Since there are no net forces acting on either ball initially (except for gravity), they continue moving straight down until they collide with something below them.

When one ball hits another, conservation of momentum applies which means total linear momentum before impact equals total linear momentum afterwards regardless of how many collisions occur between impacts provided all colliding bodies remain isolated systems throughout those interactions. Thus if Ball B has more mass than Ball A then when they make contact together they’ll move away faster along their original path while slowing down slightly due only being able to transfer part of their kinetic energy into heat because friction acts against any relative sliding motions between surfaces coming into contact under normal circumstances without lubrication present etc… However even though less overall kinetic energy gets converted into useful work like raising water levels inside tanks etc., still enough energy exists within system boundaries so long as none escapes through open ends where outside influences might enter/exit freely over time intervals much longer compared w.r.t internal timescales involved here! So far everything seems fine except perhaps regarding what happens next once both balls have bounced back upwards again following their brief encounter? Do they keep bouncing forever up & down indefinitely never stopping altogether ever since having been disturbed momentarily earlier right?

Well actually not necessarily; sooner rather later depending largely upon surface roughness / smoothness properties + elasticity characteristics too among several other factors determining just how well individual components interact dynamically together leading ultimately toward eventual equilibrium conditions where finally everything comes crashing down once again anyway simply because gravitational pull keeps pulling downwards constantly trying hard break free from whatever constraints currently holding things aloft above Earths surface level now don't ya know?! But let us suppose instead momentarily shall we...that somehow miraculously our hypothetical situation continues indefinitely without end forevermore remaining perpetually suspended high atop Mount Everest peak somewhere way out beyond human comprehension possibly even beyond God himself knows exactly why He created universe existence itself huh?? Well good luck finding such place anywhere nearby anytime soon I guess coz chances seem pretty slim indeed considering current scientific understanding about nature around us today eh?
Therefore my final conclusion would be NO - although theoretically speaking anything could happen under certain extreme circumstances involving very special geometrical configurations combined with highly unusual material properties allowing extremely low friction coefficients etc.. but realistically speaking most real-life scenarios tend NOT TO BE LIKE THAT AT ALL usually ending quite quickly instead typically within seconds minutes hours days weeks months years decades centuries millenia eons ago OR ELSE PRESENT DAY TIMESPACE DIMENSIONAL LIMITS WOULD HAVE BEEN BROKEN LONG AGO ALREADY
